Award.AwardTitle: Travel Assistance Awards for Symposium Undergraduate Research in Polymer Science at 2008 Spring National ACS Meeting in New Orleans, LA, April 6-10, 2008
Award.AbstractNarration: Intellectual merit.<br/>By providing the opportunity for participating undergraduate students to display the<br/>results of their creative academic activities at the national level, the Symposium, which is<br/>specifically dedicated to recognize and celebrate the students' exceptional work, is one of the<br/>most effective means to motivate these students and intellectually stimulate their further interest<br/>in graduate education. The symposium will give participating students a chance to discuss their<br/>research projects and exchange ideas with other students, graduate researchers, faculty and<br/>professional scientists. In addition students will practice presentation skills and gain invaluable<br/>experience presenting research at a premiere, national level, professional scientific conference.<br/><br/>Broader Impact.<br/>The symposium will serve to provide recognition to outstanding undergraduate students<br/>in polymer science and engineering, to foster networking and exposure, to introduce<br/>opportunities in graduate research and education and to help develop the careers of future leaders<br/>in both academia and industry. The symposium will also offer an occasion for students and<br/>supervising faculty to witness how student projects enhance faculty research and also serve the<br/>greater community. Additionally, it will provide motivation for future generations of<br/>undergraduate students. Those who are not engaged in these pursuits as yet can learn how their<br/>fellow students developed their research interests.<br/>"When does a scientist become a scientist? It is not when a person knows many facts and<br/>even understands in depth some aspect of the natural world. I would suggest the transition<br/>occurs when curiosity about a phenomenon leads to an inquiry for new knowledge. This can<br/>occur in a person with little or lots of knowledge about a subject. It is an attitude of inquiry".

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
